questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic with a cough and weight loss. He is suspected of having tuberculosis (TB) and is being prepared for diagnostic evaluation as per the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) guidelines.

 

Question: According to the RNTCP, how many sputum samples should be collected from a patient suspected of having tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Two sample

 

Option B:

 

The RNTCP guidelines suggest collecting 2 sputum samples for the diagnosis of TB: one spot sample at the first visit, a second early morning sample.

 

‘2 sputum smears’ over 2 days period:

 

  • Spot Sample (Day 1)
  • Morning Sample (Day 2)

 

Chances of detecting smear positive cases:

 

  • With 1 Sample : 80%
  • With 2 Sample : 93%

 

Note - Recently CBNAAT test has been added, if Sputum smear results are inconclusive or not available

 

Educational Objective:

 

Number of specimen(s) required for diagnosis of smear positive pulmonary Tuberculosis: TWO 

 

Ref: [Park 27/e p220–222, 489]

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis is diagnosed with extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) after failing to respond to first-line antitubercular therapy. He presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and night sweats. His medical history is significant for TB treatment two years ago. His sputum culture and sensitivity tests confirm resistance to both first-line and second-line drugs. The healthcare team is considering modifying his treatment regimen.

 

Question: Which of the following drugs is commonly included in the treatment regimen for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoroquinolone

 

Option B:

 

Extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) is resistant to isoniazid and rifampin (first-line drugs), any fluoroquinolone, and at least one of three injectable second-line drugs (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin). Despite this resistance pattern, fluoroquinolones remain a cornerstone in the treatment regimen for XDR-TB due to their effectiveness against mycobacteria and their ability to penetrate into various tissues, including the lungs. Adjusting the regimen to include a fluoroquinolone that the organism is less resistant to can be effective in managing XDR-TB.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amikacin: While used in some multidrug-resistant TB cases, it's often ineffective in XDR-TB due to resistance.

 

Option C. Pyrazinamide: A first-line anti-TB medication, but XDR-TB is often resistant to it.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: A second-line drug used in some TB cases, but XDR-TB is typically resistant to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The new definition of Pre-XDR-TB is: TB caused by M. tuberculosis strains that fulfil the definition of multidrug resistant and rifampicin-resistant TB (MDR/RR-TB) and which are also resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

 

The updated definition of XDR-TB is: TB caused by M. tuberculosis strains that fulfil the definition of MDR/RR-TB and which are also resistant to any fluoroquinolone and at least one additional Group A drug (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, bedaquiline and linezolid).

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p292

choices.text: The elementary body is metabolically active.
It has a biphasic life cycle.
The reticulate body divides by binary fission.
Inside the cell, it evades phagolysosome fusion.

questions.text: During a medical seminar, a lecturer erroneously includes a statement about Chlamydia trachomatis. Which of the following statements should be corrected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The elementary body is metabolically active.

 

Option A:

 

The elementary body of Chlamydia trachomatis is the infectious form and is metabolically inactive; it becomes active once it is inside the host cell, transforming into the reticulate body, which is the metabolically active form.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: True, Chlamydia trachomatis has a biphasic life cycle (elementary and reticulate bodies).

 

Option C: True, the reticulate body divides by binary fission.

 

Option D: True, Chlamydia trachomatis evades phagolysosome fusion inside the cell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Chlamydia trachomatis, particularly distinguishing between the metabolically inactive elementary body and the active reticulate body, and its mechanism of evading host defenses.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p397, 2/e p414, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1165-73, 20/e p132

questions.text: A laboratory technician is preparing to utilize a specialized staining technique for identifying intracellular pathogens in clinical specimens. Which pathogen is correctly identified using Dienes stain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycoplasma

 

Option A:


Diene’s stain is a specialized staining method used primarily for the detection of Mycoplasma species in clinical specimens. It is useful for visualizing these intracellular pathogens due to their unique developmental cycle and staining characteristics. When grown on specialized media, they form characteristic “fried egg” colonies that can be visualized using Dienes stain. 

 

 

Figure: Diene’s stain for Mycoplasma

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chlamydiae: Typically identified using Giemsa stain, immunofluorescence, or other special methods (e.g., Gimenez stain). They are not commonly identified with Dienes stain.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Identified via Wayson stain or bipolar (“safety pin”) staining, alongside culture and biochemical tests.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium diphtheriae: Demonstrated using Albert’s stain to highlight metachromatic granules or the Elek test to check for toxin production.

 

Educational Objective:


Dienes stain is a specialized method traditionally used to detect and differentiate Mycoplasma colonies in the laboratory. This staining technique is particularly valuable in identifying the distinctive elementary bodies and reticulate bodies of Mycoplasma, which are the two forms of the organism in its developmental cycle. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p407, 2/e p423, Ananthanarayan 9/e p387, 10/e p395-396

questions.text: A clinician suspects a patient has an infection with an acid-fast organism. Which of the following microorganisms is known to be acid-fast and can be identified using specific staining techniques?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atypical mycobacteria

 

Option A:

 

Atypical mycobacteria, also known as non-tuberculous mycobacteria, are a group of mycobacteria that do not cause tuberculosis or leprosy but can cause pulmonary diseases that resemble TB. These organisms are acid-fast due to the high lipid content in their cell walls, which is characteristic of the genus Mycobacterium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rickettsia is not acid-fast; it is a genus of non-motile, gram-negative, non-spore-forming, highly pleomorphic bacteria that can present as cocci, rods, or thread-like.

 

Option C. Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast due to the presence of mycolic acid in their cell walls. However, they are not typically the first organisms considered when referring to acid-fast staining.

 

Option D. Chlamydia is not acid-fast; it is a genus of pathogenic bacteria that are obligate intracellular parasites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atypical mycobacteria is acid-fast organisms. 

Other organisms which are acid fast- 

 

  • Nocarida
  • Rhodococcus
  • Smegma bacilli
  • Spermatic head
  • Spores of Bacteria
  • Cryptosporidium and Cyclospora

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p16, 2/e p16

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with tuberculosis, which of the following methods is not traditionally used for determining drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disk diffusion method

 

Option C:

 

The disk diffusion method, commonly known as the Kirby-Bauer test, is not used for testing Mycobacterium tuberculosis drug resistance due to the slow-growing nature of the organism and the need for a more controlled environment to prevent contamination and ensure accurate results. 

 

The test is not reliable for organisms requiring complex or highly specific growth environments, which includes M. tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The radiometric broth method, such as the BACTEC system, uses radioactively labeled nutrients to detect the growth of bacteria and is a standard method for determining TB drug resistance.

 

Option B. Molecular methods, like nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), can detect genetic mutations associated with resistance in TB.

 

Option D. PCR is a molecular method that can also be used to detect resistance, particularly when specific genetic mutations known to confer resistance are present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiometric broth method, Molecular method and Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) are traditionally used for determining drug resistance in tuberculosis, NOT Disk diffusion method

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p280, 2/e p291, Ananthanarayan 9/e p354, 10/e p359- 360

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, treated with immunosuppressive therapy, presents with fever, myalgia, and headache. She reports consuming homemade cheese from unpasteurized milk a week ago. Physical examination reveals a mild stiff neck and no rash. Laboratory analysis shows a white cell count of 15,000/uL with a left shift. Blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampicillin and gentamicin

 

Option B:

 

The patient's immunosuppressed state, consumption of unpasteurized dairy products, and presentation are suggestive of listeriosis. The recommended treatment for Listeria monocytogenes, especially in severe infections like bacteremia or central nervous system involvement, is ampicillin with an aminoglycoside, typically gentamicin, for synergistic effect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are the initial empirical treatment for community-acquired meningitis but would not cover Listeria, which is a concern in this immunocompromised patient.

 

Option C: Doxycycline and rifampin are not the first-line treatments for Listeria infections.

 

Option D: Ciprofloxacin alone would not adequately cover Listeria monocytogenes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In immunosuppressed individuals with suspected Listeria monocytogenes infection, the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy is ampicillin combined with an aminoglycoside like gentamicin. This combination provides effective treatment for severe listeriosis, including bacteremia and central nervous system involvement.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p296, 2/e p308, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p982-83, 20/e p1102

choices.text: Beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with corticosteroids presents with fever and altered mental status. Lumbar puncture is performed, and CSF analysis is significant for gram-positive rods. Given the patient’s immunosuppressed state and CSF findings, which of the following characteristics would most likely be associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motility at 22°C

 

Option D:

 

The patient's immunosuppressed state and the presence of gram-positive rods in the CSF suggest Listeria monocytogenes. Listeria is known for its characteristic motility at room temperature (22°C), which helps to differentiate it from other gram-positive rods.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Beta-hemolysis is not distinctive for Listeria as many other bacteria can also exhibit this property.

 

Option B: While Listeria is catalase-positive, this is not a distinguishing feature as many other gram-positive bacteria are also catalase-positive.

 

Option C: Spore formation is not a characteristic of Listeria; it is more commonly associated with genera such as Bacillus and Clostridium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distinguish Listeria monocytogenes from other gram-positive rods by its characteristic motility at room temperature, especially in the setting of an immunocompromised host with central nervous system symptoms.

​​

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p296, 2/e p308, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p982-83,20/e p1101

choices.text: Mycobacterium fortuitum and Mycobacterium chelonae
Mycobacterium gordonae and Mycobacterium szulgai
Mycobacterium xenopi and Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)

questions.text: A patient presents with a chronic skin infection that demonstrates acid-fast bacilli on biopsy. The culture reveals pigmented colonies after exposure to light. Which pair of atypical mycobacteria is known to produce pigment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium gordonae and Mycobacterium szulgai

 

Option B:

 

Mycobacterium gordonae and Mycobacterium szulgai are known to produce pigments upon exposure to light, a phenomenon known as photochromogenicity. This characteristic is used in laboratory identification of mycobacterial species.

 

 

Figure: Mycobacterium gordonae on A,B- Lowenstein Jensen Medium C.- Ogawa Medium

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium fortuitum and Mycobacterium chelonae: Incorrect because they are rapid growers but typically do not produce pigment upon light exposure.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium xenopi and Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC): Incorrect as MAC may produce pigments but not typically in response to light; M. xenopi is not known for pigment production.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium ulcerans. Incorrect because it is known for causing Buruli ulcer, not for pigment production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p360, 10/e

questions.text: A 40-year-old aquarium worker presents with a chronic, non-healing ulcer on the hand that he reports developed after sustaining a minor injury while cleaning a fish tank. A biopsy of the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation. Which mycobacterium species is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium marinum

 

Option B:

 

Mycobacterium marinum is associated with 'fish tank granuloma,' an infection typically acquired from non-chlorinated water or fish tanks. It presents as a granulomatous skin lesion following a penetrating injury from an aquatic environment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium kansasii: Incorrect as it typically causes pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium paratuberculosis: Incorrect because it is known to cause Johne's disease in cattle, not skin infections in humans.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium gordonae: Incorrect as it is generally considered a non-pathogenic environmental organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium marinum as the causative agent of granulomatous skin infections known as 'fish tank granuloma,' which occurs after direct exposure to non-chlorinated water or fish tanks.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p360, 10/e p367

questions.text: In a research lab, a scientist is studying various strains of mycobacteria. She notes that one particular strain does not belong to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTBC) group. Which of the following mycobacteria is not a member of the MTBC?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium kansasii

 

Option D:

 

The Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex (MTBC) consists of species that can cause tuberculosis in humans, including M. tuberculosis, M. africanum, and M. bovis. Mycobacterium kansasii, although it can cause tuberculosis-like diseases, is not a member of the MTBC.

 

M. tuberculosis complex includes:

 

  • M. tuberculosis : It is the most common species to cause TB in man
  • M. bovis (bovine tubercle bacillus)
  • Other members are less common human pathogens, such as M. africanum, M. microti, M. caprae, M. pinnipedii, M. canetti, M. suricattae, M. orygis, M. mungi and the recently described dassie bacillus and chimpanzee bacillus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium africanum: Incorrect as it is part of the MTBC and is known to cause tuberculosis in West Africa.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Incorrect because it is the primary causative agent of tuberculosis and is part of the MTBC.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium bovis: Incorrect as it is part of the MTBC and is also known to cause tuberculosis, primarily in cattle but also in humans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium kansasii is not a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, although it can cause tuberculosis-like diseases. It causes chronic pulmonary disease resembling tuberculosis

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p281,295, Ananthanarayan 9/e p354,359, 10/e p351

choices.text: M. tuberculosis is more pathogenic than M. bovis in humans.
M. kansasii can cause a disease indistinguishable from tuberculosis.
M. africanum infection is acquired from an environmental source.
M. marinum is responsible for tubercular lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a chronic cough, night sweats, and a recent loss of weight. He is an immigrant from a region with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. His chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. Sputum analysis is underway. The infectious disease fellow considering his case recalls studying various mycobacterial diseases and their pathogenic characteristics. Which statement is true regarding the pathogenicity of different Mycobacterium species in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M. kansasii can cause a disease indistinguishable from tuberculosis.

 

Option B:

 

Mycobacterium kansasii is known for causing pulmonary disease that closely resembles tuberculosis, both clinically and radiographically. It can produce symptoms such as cough, weight loss, and night sweats, similar to M. tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. M. tuberculosis is more pathogenic than M. bovis in humAns. Incorrect as M. bovis also causes tuberculosis in humans, but its pathogenicity can be less due to pasteurization of milk.

 

Option C. M. africanum infection is acquired from an environmental source: Incorrect because M. africanum, like M. tuberculosis, is primarily transmitted from person to person via respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. M. marinum is responsible for tubercular lymphadenopathy: Incorrect as M. marinum typically causes skin infections associated with aquatic environments, not lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

M. kansasii can cause a pulmonary disease that is clinically and radiographically indistinguishable from tuberculosis caused by M. tuberculosis. M. tuberculosis and M. bovis both cause tuberculosis in humans, but M. bovis is less commonly encountered. M. africanum causes tuberculosis similar to M. tuberculosis but is not typically acquired from environmental sources. M. marinum causes skin infections and is not known for causing tubercular lymphadenopathy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p283, 2/e p295, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1229, 20/e p1267

choices.text: Stool antigen test for H. pylori
Urea breath test for H. pylori
Histological examination of a gastric biopsy

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with recurrent epigastric pain is diagnosed with a peptic ulcer via endoscopy. She has no previous history of H. pylori treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the etiology of her peptic ulcer disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urea breath test for H. pylori

 

Option C:

 

The urea breath test is a highly sensitive and specific non-invasive test for diagnosing active H. pylori infection. It is especially useful when there is no previous history of H. pylori eradication therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The stool antigen test can also be used to diagnose active infection but is less specific than the urea breath test.

 

Option B: Serology is not appropriate for diagnosing active infection as it cannot differentiate between past and current infections.

 

Option D: Histological examination is invasive and usually reserved for cases where endoscopy is already indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea breath test is the most appropriate non-invasive test for diagnosing active H. pylori infection in a patient with a peptic ulcer, if no previous eradication therapy taken by patient.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e, p379

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a chronic skin condition. On examination, several distinctive facial features are noted, which are suggestive of a longstanding mycobacterial infection. Which of the following features is commonly seen in patients with untreated Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Leonine facies

 

Option D:

 

Leonine facies, characterized by facial thickening due to skin infiltration and nodularity, is a classical feature of lepromatous leprosy. It is associated with the advanced stage of the disease and results from the infiltration of Mycobacterium leprae into the facial skin.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Saddle nose: Incorrect, while this can be seen in leprosy due to destruction of the nasal septum, it is not as characteristic as leonine facies. It is characteristic of congenital syphilis, Untreated early syphilis infections can cause saddle nose deformity,

 

Option B. Small earlobe: Incorrect, as this is not a recognized feature of leprosy.

 

Option C. Ptosis: Incorrect, as ptosis is not typically a feature of leprosy but may occur secondary to facial nerve involvement in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic facial feature of leonine facies is a classical feature of lepromatous leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p299

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of dyspepsia undergoes an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. A biopsy from the gastric antrum shows a positive result on the rapid urease test, and culture on selective media yields a curved, gram-negative rod. Which organism is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Helicobacter pylori

 

Option B:

 

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative, curved rod that is a common cause of chronic gastritis and peptic ulcer disease. The rapid urease test is commonly used during endoscopy to detect the presence of H. pylori in the gastric mucosa due to the organism's ability to produce urease. Growth on selective Skirrow's media is also indicative of H. pylori, which distinguishes it from other potential organisms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Campylobacter jejuni can cause gastroenteritis and is also a curved gram-negative rod, but it is not typically associated with peptic ulcers and does not grow on Skirrow's media.

 

Option C: Proteus mirabilis is a gram-negative rod with swarming motility, known for urinary tract infections, and does not usually colonize the gastric mucosa or grow on Skirrow's media.

 

Option D: While E. coli is a common gram-negative rod bacterium, it is more typically associated with intestinal infections and does not exhibit the curved shape or the specific urease activity in the gastric mucosa that is characteristic of H. pylori infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Helicobacter pylori is the cause of gastritis and peptic ulcer disease based on positive rapid urease testing and growth on Skirrow's media during gastric biopsy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p363-64, 2/e p378-379, Ananthanarayan 9/e p400,401, 10/e p407-408

choices.text: Patients who have received the lepromin test
Patients undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy

questions.text: A dermatologist is treating a patient with lepromatous leprosy who develops tender erythematous nodules on the skin and complains of systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. This acute inflammatory complication is known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL). Which patient population is most commonly affected by this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patients with lepromatous leprosy (LL)

 

Option C:

 

Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) is an immune complex-mediated complication that occurs predominantly in patients with lepromatous leprosy, the multibacillary form of the disease. It is characterized by painful nodules, systemic symptoms, and can be precipitated by immune system changes during treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patients who have received the lepromin test: Incorrect as ENL is not caused by the lepromin test, which is a skin test used in leprosy.

 

Option B. Patients undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy: Incorrect as ENL is not directly caused by the therapy but can be a reaction associated with immune changes during treatment.

 

Option D. Patients with tuberculoid leprosy (TT): Incorrect because ENL is much less common in the paucibacillary form of the disease, such as tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) is indeed an immune complex-mediated complication primarily occurring in patients with lepromatous leprosy (LL), which is the multibacillary form of leprosy. ENL is characterized by painful nodules and systemic symptoms and can be triggered by changes in the immune system during treatment.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p299, Park 23/e p324, 24/e p342

choices.text: It is typically negative in children under 6 months of age.
It is a diagnostic test for leprosy.
It is used to classify the form of leprosy.
A BCG vaccine may convert a negative lepromin test to positive.

questions.text: A medical researcher is assessing the utility of various tests in the diagnosis and management of leprosy. Regarding the lepromin skin test, which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a diagnostic test for leprosy.

 

Option B:

 

The lepromin test is not used for the diagnosis of leprosy; rather, it is used to determine the type of immune response to Mycobacterium leprae and to classify the form of leprosy (tuberculoid vs. lepromatous). A positive test suggests a tuberculoid form, which has a better prognosis, while a negative test is more indicative of the lepromatous form.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is typically negative in children under 6 months of age: Correct, as infants have an immature immune response.

 

Option C. It is used to classify the form of leprosy: Correct, as it helps differentiate between paucibacillary and multibacillary disease.

 

Option D. A BCG vaccine may convert a negative lepromin test to positive: Correct, as both the BCG vaccine and lepromin test are based on immune responses to mycobacterial antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lepromin test is indeed used to classify the form of leprosy rather than for diagnostic purposes. A positive result indicates a tuberculoid form with a better prognosis, while a negative result is more suggestive of the lepromatous form. The test is typically negative in children under 6 months of age due to their immature immune response, it is used for classification, and the BCG vaccine can convert a negative lepromin test to positive as both are based on immune responses to mycobacterial antigens.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p290, 2/e p301-302, Park 23/e p320, 24/e p338

questions.text: A clinician is discussing the long-term management of a patient who has completed treatment for multibacillary leprosy. For how many years should the patient be monitored annually to ensure no relapse occurs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 years

 

Option B:

 

According to WHO guidelines, patients who have completed treatment for multibacillary leprosy should be followed up annually for at least 5 years to monitor for any signs of relapse, as the risk of relapse remains significant for several years post-treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Operational Classification of Leprosy (according to skin smear positivity) to serve as a basis for Chemotherapy

 

 

OAMS: Once a month supervised

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p291, 2/e p301-302, Ref:  Park 23/e p323, 24/e p341-342

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing the World Health Organization's recommended treatment regimens for leprosy. Which of the following medications is NOT included in the standard WHO-recommended treatment regimen for leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciprofloxacin

 

Option B:

 

The WHO-recommended treatment regimen for leprosy includes dapsone, clofazimine, and rifampicin. Ciprofloxacin is not part of the standard regimen for leprosy and is generally used for other bacterial infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Incorrect as it is a key component of both paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy treatment regimens.

 

Option C. Clofazimine: Incorrect as it is included in the treatment regimen for multibacillary leprosy.

 

Option D. Rifampicin: Incorrect because it is used in the treatment of both paucibacillary and multibacillary leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WHO 3 drug Regimen (2018)
    • Dapsone (100 mg) is given daily, self-administered
    • Rifampicin (600 mg) is given once a month under supervision
    • Clofazimine (300 mg) is given once a month under supervision, and by 50 mg daily, self-administered

 

Duration of treatment—6 months for paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary leprosy. Follow-up is conducted annually for 2 years for paucibacillary leprosy and for five years for multibacillary leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p291, 2/e p301-302, Ref:  Park 23/e p323, 24/e p341-342

questions.text: In the clinic, a physician is prescribing a treatment regimen for a patient with newly diagnosed paucibacillary leprosy. For how long should dapsone be continued in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 months

 

Option A:

 

For paucibacillary leprosy, the WHO recommends a fixed-duration multidrug therapy (MDT) for 6 months, which includes dapsone and rifampicin. This regimen is effective and helps prevent the development of drug resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duration of treatment—6 months for paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary leprosy. Follow-up is conducted annually for 2 years for paucibacillary leprosy and for five years for multibacillary leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p291, 2/e p301-302, Park 23/e p323,  24/e p341

choices.text: < 100 bacilli per oil immersion field
1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields
No bacilli in all fields

questions.text: A laboratory technician is performing a smear test for leprosy and observes bacilli under the microscope. To quantify the bacterial load, the technician refers to the bacteriological index (BI). What does a bacteriological index of 1+ indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields

 

Option B:

 

A bacteriological index (BI) of 1+ indicates a bacterial load of 1–10 bacilli per 100 oil immersion fields on a smear from a leprosy patient. This semi-quantitative scale helps to assess the bacterial burden and the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. < 100 bacilli per oil immersion field: Incorrect as this does not correspond to the standardized BI scale for 1+.

 

Option C. No bacilli in all fields: Incorrect because the presence of any bacilli indicates a BI greater than zero.

 

Option D. Bacilli in all fields: Incorrect as this would suggest a higher BI than 1+.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial/Bacteriological index (BI): Density of bacilli in smears, including both living and dead bacilli

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p290, 2/e p300, Park, 24/e p337

questions.text: An infectious disease specialist is comparing the Madrid and Indian classifications for leprosy. Which type of leprosy is included in the Indian classification but NOT in the Madrid classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pure neuritic type leprosy

 

Option D:

 

The Indian classification of leprosy includes pure neuritic leprosy, which is characterized by nerve involvement without the typical skin lesions. This category is not present in the Madrid classification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Indeterminate leprosy: Incorrect as it is included in both classifications.

 

Option B. Borderline leprosy: Incorrect because it is recognized in both classifications.

 

Option C. Tuberculoid leprosy: Incorrect as it is a part of both classification systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p286, 2/e p297, Park 24/e p335

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of leprosy comes to the clinic for a follow-up. The physician knows that leprosy can affect multiple organ systems. Which of the following is NOT typically affected by leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovary

 

Option B:

 

Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, can affect multiple organs, including the nerves (leading to neuropathy), eyes (leading to blindness), and testes (leading to infertility). The ovaries, however, are not typically affected by leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Testes: Incorrect as leprosy can affect the testes, causing gynecomastia and infertility.

 

Option C. Eye: Incorrect because leprosy can involve the eye, leading to blindness.

 

Option D. Nerve: Incorrect as nerve involvement is one of the hallmark features of leprosy, leading to numbness and muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy can involve the testes (causing gynecomastia and infertility), eyes (leading to blindness), and nerves (resulting in numbness and muscle weakness). It is essential to note that ovarian involvement is not a common manifestation of leprosy.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p288, 2/e p298, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1124, 20/e p1261, Internet source

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with a diagnosis of lepromatous leprosy presents with an acute onset of erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL). He is already on a multidrug therapy regimen.

 

Which of the following medications is NOT typically used in the management of type II lepra reaction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chloroquine

 

Option A:

 

Thalidomide, cyclosporine, and corticosteroids are used in the management of type II lepra reaction, which is characterized by painful nodules, fever, and systemic involvement. Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug and has no primary role in the management of ENL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thalidomide: Incorrect because it is specifically used for ENL due to its immunomodulatory effects.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Incorrect as it may be used as an immunosuppressant in severe cases of ENL.

 

Option D. Corticosteroid: Incorrect because corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for acute ENL due to their potent anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloroquine as not typically used in the management of type II lepra reactions, in contrast to thalidomide, cyclosporine, and corticosteroids, which are used to treat this condition.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p291, 2/e p299, Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine19/e p1125, 20/e p1262

choices.text: Consists of macrophages filled with acid-fast bacilli (AFB)
Consists of neutrophils filled with bacteria

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a skin biopsy from a patient with lepromatous leprosy under the microscope. When considering the histological findings, which of the following is true regarding globi in a patient with lepromatous leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Consists of macrophages filled with acid-fast bacilli (AFB)

 

Option B:

 

Globi in lepromatous leprosy refer to clusters of macrophages filled with numerous acid-fast bacilli, which are characteristic of the diffuse, unchecked multiplication of Mycobacterium leprae in this form of leprosy.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Consists of lipid-laden macrophages: Incorrect as this description is more indicative of foam cells, which are not the same as globi.

 

Option C. Consists of neutrophils filled with bacteria: Incorrect because neutrophils are not the primary cells that contain bacilli in leprosy.

 

Option D. Consists of activated lymphocytes: Incorrect as globi are not comprised of lymphocytes but of macrophages filled with AFB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globi in lepromatous leprosy are clusters of macrophages filled with a high number of acid-fast bacilli.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p289, 2/e p300, Ananthanarayan 9/e p364, 10/e p373

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing facts about leprosy for an upcoming exam. She reads several statements to determine their accuracy. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In paucibacillary leprosy, more than 2 nerves are involved.

 

Option C:

 

Paucibacillary leprosy is characterized by the involvement of fewer than five skin lesions and typically involves only one nerve. The statement regarding more than 2 nerves being involved is incorrect and would suggest multibacillary leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multibacillary leprosy means the person has six or more skin lesions: Correct, as this is part of the WHO's classification for leprosy.

 

Option B. Regular multidrug therapy (MDT) means patients received 2/3rd of months of treatment schedule: Correct, as it describes the WHO's recommended treatment compliance rate.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation may be present in leprosy: Correct, as sensory loss is a common feature due to nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While, Paucibacillary leprosy is characterized by one to five skin lesions and typically involves fewer nerves, usually not more than one. It is less severe than multibacillary leprosy and involves a lesser bacterial load. In, Multibacillary leprosy six or more skin lesions observed. This form of leprosy represents a more severe disease with a higher bacterial load.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p291, 2/e p297, Park 24/e p336
